column1: Uthai Thani (Thai: อุทัยธานี
column3: one of Thailand's seventy-six provinces (changwat) lies in lower northern Thailand. Neighboring provinces are (from north clockwise) Nakhon Sawan
column6: Kanchanaburi and Tak. It lies somewhat off the route between Bangkok

column1: The province stretches from the upper plains of the Chao Phraya River valley
column2: to forested mountains in the west. The Sakae Krang River
column3: a tributary of the Chao Phraya River
column4: is the main watercourse of in the province.

column1: The Huai Kha Khaeng Wildlife Sanctuary
column2: at the western boundary bordering Tak Province
column3: was declared a World Heritage Site in 1991. It covers 2
column4: 574 km2 and is home to most of the forest animals of Southeast Asia

column1: Originally Mon and Lawa settled in the area. The first Thai settlement in the area was Muang U Thai during the Sukhothai Kingdom
column2: but it was later abandoned when the river changed course. The Patabeut people
column4: revived the settlement at its current site during the Ayutthaya Kingdom. It served as a fort protecting the boundary of the kingdom.

column1: Uthai Thani is the hometown of the father of King Rama I. Rama I renamed the city from its old name Uthai to Uthai Thani.

column2: King Chulalongkorn (Rama V) added the area of Uthai Thani to the Monthon Nakhon Sawan and in 1898 formed the province.

column1: The provincial seal depicts the pavilion at Wat Khao Sakae Krang. It houses the statue of Thongdee
column2: the father of King Rama I and a Buddha footprint. The mountain in the background symbolizes the location of the pavilion on top of Khao Sakae Krang.The provincial flower is the yellow cotton tree (Cochlospermum regium). The provincial tree is the neem (Azadirachta indica v. siamensis).

column1: The flag of Uthai Thani depicts the provincial seal of Uthai Thani in the middle. The yellow colour at the top of the flag is the colour of the Chakri dynasty
column2: symbolizing gold. The green colour at the bottom is the colour of King Rama I as he was born on a Wednesday
column3: which is associated with green in the Thai calendar. The text below the seal says Uthai Thani Province.

column1: The province is divided into eight districts (amphoes). These are further divided into 70 subdistricts (tambons) and 642 villages (mubans).

As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Uthai Thani Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 14 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Uthai Thani has town (thesaban mueang) status. There are a further 13 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 49 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations (SAO) (ongkan borihan suan tambon).

column2: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Thailand began tracking progress on human development at the sub-national level using the Human Achievement Index (HAI)
column3: a composite index covering eight key areas of human development. The National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) took over this task in 2017.
